questions.text: During the dissection class, a professor asks you to name the nerve that innervates the muscle labeled as A. He gives a clue that the nerve will also innervate the rhomboid minor and major. Identify the nerve.
questions.solution:
Muscle A is the levator scapulae, which is innervated by the dorsal scapular nerve. It also supplies the rhomboid major and minor.

The dorsal scapular nerve originates from the C5 root of the brachial plexus, passes posteriorly, and often pierces the middle scalene muscle in the neck. It then travels along the medial border of the scapula and innervates the rhomboid major and minor muscles. It also innervates the levator scapulae along with branches directly from the anterior rami of the C3 and C4 spinal nerves.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man with a known history of bronchial asthma presented with acute breathlessness, tachycardia, and agitation. Pulse oximetry was 85% on room air. Identify the correct sequence of events that are occurring in the carotid bodies in response to the current state.
  1. Inactivation of potassium channels
  2. Depolarization
  3. Decreased efflux of potassium
  4. Excitation of afferent nerve
  5. Calcium influx
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of acute exacerbation of bronchial asthma where the patient is hypoxic (pulse oximetry of 85%). The correct sequence regarding the response to hypoxia is 1-3-2-5-4.

Type I glomus cells in the carotid and aortic bodies have O2-sensitive K+ channels, which are inactivated in response to hypoxia. This reduces the K+ efflux, depolarizing the cell and causing Ca2+ inﬂux, via L-type voltage-gated calcium channels. The Ca2+ influx triggers action potentials and consequent excitation of the afferent nerve endings.

The smooth muscle cells in the pulmonary arteries contain similar O2-sensitive K+ channels, which mediate the vasoconstriction caused by hypoxia. Systemic arteries contain ATP-sensitive K+ channels that allow K+ efflux in response to hypoxia leading to vasodilation instead of vasoconstriction.

Since there is a large blood flow per unit of tissue in the carotid bodies, the O2 needs of the cells are met largely by dissolved O2 alone. The receptors are not stimulated in anemia or carbon monoxide poisoning, since the dissolved O2 in the blood reaching the receptors is generally normal, even though the combined oxygen in the blood is decreased.

The receptors are stimulated when:

  • Low arterial Po2 
  • Vascular stasis- the amount of O2 delivered to the receptors per unit time is decreased
  • Cyanide - prevents O2 utilization at the tissue level
  • Nicotine in sufficient doses activates the chemoreceptors
  • Infusion of K+ increases the discharge rate in chemoreceptor afferents

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the OPD by his parents. They complained that their son found climbing stairs and walking long distances difficult. His teachers also complained that his handwriting was gradually getting worse.  They found that he was getting clumsy over the past month and would mumble while talking. On examination, the doctor notices an over-arched foot, depressed deep tendon reflexes, and extensor plantar reflexes. An X-ray of the spine was ordered which showed the following image. An echocardiogram done shows an enlarged heart. What is the trinucleotide repeat associated with this disorder?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features showing progressive ataxia, dysarthria, clumsiness, depressed deep tendon reflexes, pes cavus, cardiomyopathy and x-ray showing scoliosis are highly suggestive of Friedreich ataxia. It is caused by an expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat related to chromosome 9q13.

It is an autosomal-recessive disease with progressive ataxia, spasticity, weakness, sensory neuropathy, and cardiomyopathy. Deep tendon reflexes are depressed or absent, but an extensor plantar reflex is typically present.

The expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat on chromosome 9q13, encodes frataxin, a protein found in the mitochondrial inner membrane where it is involved in the assembly of iron-sulfur cluster enzymes of complex I and II. Affected individuals have extremely low levels of protein.

Patients become wheelchair-bound within 5 years of onset and the life expectancy is up to 40-50 years of age. Cardiomyopathy is associated with arrhythmias and congestive heart failure which eventually contributes to the affected individual's death

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not caused by pseudomonas aeroginosa?
questions.solution:
Glanders disease is not caused by pseudomonas. Causative organism for Glander’s disease is Burkholderia Mallei.

Diseases caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa:

  • Shanghai fever: self-limited febrile illness
  • Jacuzzi syndrome (Hot tub folliculitis/Pseudomonas aeruginosa folliculitis) is a common type of folliculitis, which causes inflammation of hair follicles.
  • Scromboid poisoning: It is one of the most common causes of morbidity associated with fish intake which have not been refrigerated properly from the time they were caught until the time they were served. Bacteria act on compounds in the fish, releasing histamine. Process is induced by enzymes produced by primarily enteric gram-negative bacteria (e.g., Morganella morganii, Escherichia coli, Klebsiella species and Pseudomonas aeruginosa) found in the fish's cutis and intestines.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man, who is a bachelor, living alone in a rented home is brought to the casualty. His initial symptoms included nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension and pain. Later his symptoms progressed to dry mouth, dysarthria, blurring of vision and muscle weakness. It is found that he might have consumed expired food from the containers found in his house, as shown below. Considering the suspected diagnosis, what specific category of treatment would you consider as appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
The characteristic clinical history along with canned food shown in the image is suggestive of foodborne botulism caused by Clostridium botulinum. It is treated with Botulinum antitoxin one vial by slow IV in normal saline and one vial IM and repeated at 2 to 4-hour intervals IV. 

Clostridium botulinum toxin types A, B, E cause disease in humans. Type E is often associated with fish and other seafood. It multiplies in the food, e.g., sausages, tinned meat, fish, fruits, etc. before it is consumed, and produces a powerful exotoxin under suitable anaerobic conditions. The fatal dose for an adult is 0.01 mg. or even less. 

Symptoms usually begin 12-36 hours after ingestion. m. The initial GI symptoms include nausea, vomiting, abdominal distension, and pain. Later symptoms are dry or sore mouth or throat, difficulty with visual accommodation, dysphonia, diplopia, ptosis, dysarthria, blurring of vision, muscle weakness, descending bilaterally symmetrical motor paralysis initiated by abducent (VI) or oculomotor (III) nerve palsy, dysphagia, constipation, respiratory insufficiency, and urinary retention. The patient is conscious until death, which is preceded by coma or delirium.

All the pathogenic effects are caused by a powerful exotoxin produced by the organism. Botulinum toxin acts by blocking the production and release of acetylcholine at the synapses and neuromuscular junction.

Site of action: neuromuscular junctions, postganglionic parasympathetic nerve endings, and peripheral ganglia.

Clinical use :

  • It is used in the treatment of neuromuscular disorders like strabismus, blepharospasm, wrinkle, myoclonus (since botulism toxin produces flaccid paralysis).
  • The action is short-lasting and recovery occurs in 2-4 months once the new terminal axon sprouts form and restore transmission.
  • Blocking of acetylcholine release from nerve terminal is permanent and recovery occurs only by sprouting of new nerve
    terminals.

At autopsy, the kidneys, liver, and meninges are congested. Histological examination of the organs may show thrombosis.

Treatment:

  • Gastric lavage or emesis.
  • Activated charcoal.
  • Purgative (sorbitol). 
  • Whole bowel irrigation.
  • Botulinum antitoxin (types A, B and E) one vial (50,000 to 1,00,000 units) by slow i.v. in normal saline and one vial i.m., and repeated at 2 to 4-hour intervals i.v. 
  • Botulism immune globulin (BIG) is a pentavalent types A, B, C, D, and E. 50 ml is given i.v. daily, till the patient recovers.
  • Guanidine 15 to 40 mg/kg/day orally. It reverses the neuromuscular block of botulism.
  • Adequate respiration.
  • Alcohol precipitates toxin; frequent small doses of brandy are beneficial.

questions.text: A 14-year-old female patient presents to your clinic with nasal obstruction. Physical examination revealed a wide, roomy nasal cavity, a pale nasal mucosa and greyish-black dry crusts that improved after modified Young's procedure. Identify the clinical feature likely to be associated with this condition.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of atrophic rhinitis, and merciful anosmia is associated with this condition. Merciful anosmia is when the patient has marked anosmia and is unable to smell the foul odor coming from their nose.

Atrophic rhinitis is a chronic inflammation of the nose characterized by atrophy of the nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. It is more common in females and starts around puberty. The patient presents with nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers. It is associated with foul odor from their nose but the patient is unable to smell it because of merciful anosmia. Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements. On examination nasal mucosa appears pale, greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. 

Medical management is done using warm saline for nasal irrigation, removal of crusts and administering local antibiotics like kemicetine antiozaena solution(containing chloromycetin, oestradiol, and vitamin D2).

Surgical management involves:

  • In Young's operation, both the nostrils are closed completely by raising flaps within the nasal vestibule. They are opened after 6 months and during this time, the mucosa comes back to normal and the crusting is reduced.
  • Modified young operation is a modified version of Young's operation where the nostrils are only partially closed. The results are the same compared to Young's operation and it is done to avoid discomfort from complete closure of the nostrils. 

Other options:

Option A: Offensive cheesy discharge is seen in an uncommon condition called rhinitis caseosa. It is usually unilateral and affects males. The disease arises from chronic sinusitis with the collection of inspissated cheesy material.

Option C: Paroxysmal sneezing refers to bouts of sneezing in the morning and is associated with allergic rhinitis and vasomotor rhinitis. 

Option D: Allergic salute is the constant upward rubbing motion of the nose simulating a salute, leading to transverse nasal crease across the dorsum of the nose. Seen in allergic rhinitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Atrophic Rhinitis

Atrophic rhinitis is more common in females and usually starts at puberty. It is a bilateral condition.

  • Symptoms:
    • Foul smell from the nose
    • Nasal obstruction in spite of roomy chambers due to large crusts filling nasal cavity
    • Epistaxis on removing of the crusts
    • Anosmia due to degeneration of nerve elements (merciful anosmia).
  • Signs:
    • Greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum
    • After removal of crusts, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
    • Nasal mucosa appears pale.

Related Pearl: Etiology of atrophic rhinitis

Etiology of primary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Hereditary- Involves more than one member of a family
  • Endocrinal- More common in females, starts at puberty and regresses after menopause
  • Racial- More common in mongoloid and caucasian races
  • Nutritional deficiency- Vitamin A, D, iron deficiencies
  • Autoimmune- Antigens of the nasal mucosa
  • Organism- Klebsiella ozaenae

Etiology of secondary atrophic rhinitis:

  • Specific infections like syphilis, lupus, leprosy and, rhinoscleroma
  • Long-standing purulent sinusitis
  • Radiotherapy to nose
  • Excessive surgical removal of turbinates
  • Diphtheroids, Proteus vulgaris, Escherichia coli, staphylococci and streptococci

questions.text: A study to determine the association between maternal smoking during pregnancy and low birth weight is being carried out. It involves obtaining smoking histories from pregnant women during their antenatal visits and then subsequently assessing the birth weight of their babies soon after delivery. What type of study is this?
questions.solution:
The study of choice is a prospective cohort study. This study is a prospective cohort study because the subjects (pregnant women) were categorized on the basis of exposure or lack of exposure to a risk factor -smoking during pregnancy. They were followed to determine if the outcome, the low birth weight of the babies occurred or not.
 
A prospective cohort study is a study in which the outcome has not yet occurred at the time that the investigations begin. They begin in the present and continue into the future. The design of a prospective cohort is shown below.
A retrospective cohort study is when both the exposure and outcome have occurred before the investigations and study is undertaken. An example would be if the charts in a hospital from the previous year were reviewed, and mothers were classified as smokers or nonsmokers based on records. The records are then followed through time and then the birth weight of the children in both groups are compared. It is also called a historical cohort study, a prospective study in retrospect, or a non-concurrent prospective study.
 
In a case-control study of the same, low birth weight infants would be selected as the cases and normal birth weight babies as the controls. The frequency of maternal smoking would then be compared in the two groups.
 
In cross-sectional studies, exposure and outcome are measured at the same point in time.

Related Pearl: Cohort Study

  • A cohort study progresses from cause (exposure) to effect (disease).
  • It is also known as forward-looking study, incidence study, prospective study, and longitudinal study.
  • Design of a cohort study:
    • Types of cohort study:
      • Prospective (concurrent) cohort studies
      • Retrospective (historical) cohort studies
      • Combination cohort studies
    • Steps of cohort study:
      • Selection of study subjects
      • Obtaining data on exposure
      • Selection of comparison groups
      • Follow-up
      • Analysis in terms of incidence rates and estimation of risk
    • Advantages of cohort study:
      • Incidence can be calculated
      • Several possible outcomes related to exposure can be studied at the same time
      • Provides direct estimate of relative risk
      • Calculation of dose-response ratio
      • Minimization of certain biases
    • Disadvantages of cohort study:
      • Cannot use for uncommon diseases
      • Expensive, requires a large population and longer time
      • Many common administrative and ethical problems
      • High attrition and selection of subjects is difficult
      • Dynamism of diagnostics is difficult to incorporate
      • Tends to alter the behaviour of subjects known as Hawthorne effect.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: Which of the following conditions show “Maltese cross” appearance of urinary casts under polarized light?
questions.solution:
Urine analysis in Fabry’s disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarized light showing a "Maltese cross” appearance. It can also be seen in nephrotic syndrome.

Interpretation of casts in urine:

  • Hyaline casts: Physiological, concentrated urine, fever, exercise
  • Red blood cell casts: Glomerular causes
  • White blood cells casts: Pyelonephritis, interstitial nephritis
  • Muddy brown casts: Acute tubular necrosis, interstitial nephritis
  • Fatty casts: Heavy proteinuria
  • Broad casts: Chronic renal failure

Maltese cross appearance elsewhere:

  • Short-range shotgun wound
  • Babesiosis

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman came with complaints of post-menopausal bleed. She is a known diabetic and hypertensive for the past 15 years. She was diagnosed to have endometrial carcinoma. Which among the following is the gold standard investigation in staging endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Surgery is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

Endometrial carcinoma is surgically staged according to the Joint 2010 International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics (FIGO)/TNM classification system.

Total extra-fascial hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy and pelvic and para-aortic lymph node dissection is the standard staging procedure for endometrial carcinoma. 

When a patient is staged only clinically, contrast-enhanced magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) appears to be the best radiographic modality for detecting myometrial invasion or cervical involvement.

Hysteroscopy and biopsy visualizes the entire uterine lining and select biopsy from suspicious areas; both reduce the chances of missing the lesion. Even then, this is not 100% predictive, as an early lesion can be missed.

Recently, the concern has been raised regarding the spilling of cancer cells into the peritoneal cavity during hysteroscopy.

PET–CT reveals metabolic activity in the tissue and is highly sensitive and specific for detecting positive pelvic and/or para-aortic lymphadenopathy as well as distant metastases in selected high-risk patients with endometrial cancer.

questions.text: Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which did not subside even after 3 weeks of birth, was observed in a neonate. On investigating, liver enzymes, PT/INR and albumin levels were normal. No hemolysis was seen on a peripheral blood smear. A drop in bilirubin level was observed within a week after treating with phenobarbital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Jaundice persisiting 3 weeks after birth is suggestive of pathological jaundice. Among the given options, Crigler Najjar type 2 presents with unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia which responds to phenobarbital therapy.  

Dubin Johnson (option C) and Rotor (option A) syndromes lead to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. 

Crigler Najjar type 2 is an autosomal recessive disease with non-hemolytic, unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia caused by homozygous missense mutations in the enzyme UDP UGT1A1 resulting in reduced (partial) enzymatic activity.

The differences between Crigler-Najjar type 1 and type 2 are described in the table below:

Autosomal recessive   Autosomal recessive
UDPGT is absent   UDPGT is reduced
Severe unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia   Less severe
Pale stools   Normal-coloured stools
May proceed to kernicterus and does not respond to phenobarbitone   Does not proceed to kernicterus and is responsive to phenobarbitone

questions.text: During a preoperative anesthetic evaluation, pharmacologic stress echocardiography is being undertaken for a patient with chronic pulmonary disease. Which of the following agents can be used for inducing pharmacological stress in this patient?
questions.solution:
Dobutamine can be used for the induction of pharmacological stress in a patient with chronic pulmonary disease.

Dobutamine is a potent β-receptor agonist used for stress testing. It increases myocardial oxygen demand by increasing contractility, heart rate, and blood pressure in a similar manner as exercise. Dobutamine stress testing is the preferred choice for the assessment of myocardial viability and is generally used as an alternative to vasodilator stress in patients with chronic pulmonary disease, where vasodilators are contraindicated.  

Cardiac stress testing is performed in patients with known or suspected coronary artery disease. It is also done for preoperative CVS monitoring in a patient with risk factors for myocardial infarction. Generally, exercise stress testing is preferred because it provides information on functional capacity, exercise tolerance, and symptom provocation. However, some patients undergo pharmacologic stress testing. Indications for pharmacologic stress testing include: 

  • Unstable angina
  • Inability to exercise
  • History of uncontrolled heart failure at risk for deterioration
  • Poorly controlled blood pressure
  • History of aortic stenosis
  • Recent myocardial infarction
  • Acute pulmonary embolism
  • Acute pericarditis or myocarditis
  • Severe pulmonary hypertension
  • Chronic pulmonary disease

Vasodilators are the most commonly used pharmacologic stressors for myocardial perfusion imaging. Vasodilator stress acts by increasing and diverting blood flow to the non-diseased blood vessels so that the diseased vessels can be visualized clearly. It is brought about by drugs such as adenosine, dipyridamole, and regadenoson.

Contraindications to vasodilator stress testing are:

  • Pronounced active bronchospastic airway disease
  • Significant hypotension

questions.text: A 30-year-old man met with an accident and fell with his hand in dorsiflexion. On examination, there is swelling and tenderness around the wrist joint. The X-ray shown below confirmed the diagnosis, following which Tavernier's maneuver successfully corrected the condition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and treatment with Tavernier's maneuver point to a perilunate dislocation.

The X-ray of perilunate dislocation shows the lunate maintaining its normal articulation with the radius, whereas other carpal bones have dislocated from the lunate dorsally. It is frequently associated with compression of the median nerve. 

Prompt reduction reduces swelling and potential damage to the median nerve. The most commonly used method of closed reduction is the Tavernier maneuver. It consists of locking the capitate into the distal concavity of the lunate. When the injury cannot be reduced this way, urgent reduction in theatre should be done.

In lunate dislocation, the lunate dislocates anteriorly and the rest of the carpal bones remain in place.

In scapholunate dissociation (SLD), a large gap may be present between the scaphoid and lunate on X-ray which is known as the Terry Thomas sign. It was named after Terry Thomas, a comedian who had a gap-toothed smile.

An X-ray showing scapholunate dislocation is shown below.

In lunotriquetral dislocation, the X-ray changes are usually subtle. But sometimes the X-ray shows a gap between lunate and triquetrum, and forward titling of lunate and scaphoid in the lateral view.

questions.text: USG mode used in echocardiography is _______
questions.solution:
M-mode USG is used for echocardiography.

The echo intensity is displayed as brightness and the trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Modes in USG:

  • A mode – Amplitude mode - Used in Ophthalmology and orbital biometry 
  • B mode/ Grayscale used for all routine application
  • M mode – Echocardiography (Motion)

Advantage of USG – No radiation and is portable

The disadvantage of USG – operator dependence

USG has preferred investigation for:

  • Gall bladder pathology
  • Cyst
  • Fluid collection like ascites, pleural effusion, and pericardial effusion
  • Initial evaluation of jaundice
  • USG is the safest radiological investigation for pregnant female

Therapeutic application of USG – HIFU (high intensity focussed USG) useful for the treatment of fibroid. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high powered ultrasound beams that are tightly focused so that very small target tissue can be heated and coagulated.

questions.text: An IT employee is feeling guilty, hopeless, and not able to concentrate on work. His symptoms started 3 years back when he entered college. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of guilt, hopelessness, and difficulty in concentrating over a period of more than 2 years, is suggestive of dysthymia (persistent depressive disorder).

The DSM 5 and ICD-11 criteria for diagnosis of dysthymia: 

A. Depressed mood for most of the day as indicated by either subjective account or observation by others, for at least 2 years. In children and adolescents at least 1 year.

B. Presence of two (or more) of the following while being depressed.

  1. Poor appetite or overeating
  2. Insomnia or hypersomnia
  3. Low energy or fatigue
  4. Low self-esteem
  5. Poor concentration and/or difficulty making decisions
  6. Feelings of hopelessness

C. During the 2-year period (1 year for children or adolescents) of the disturbance, the individ­ual has never been without the symptoms in criteria A and B for more than 2 months at a time.

D. Criteria for a major depressive disorder may be continuously present for 2 years.

E. There has never been a manic episode or a hypomanic episode, and criteria have never been met for cyclothymic disorder.

F. The disturbance is not better explained by a persistent schizoaffective disorder, schizophrenia, delusional disorder, or other specified or unspecified schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders.

G. The symptoms are not attributable to the physiological effects of a substance (e.g., a drug of abuse, a medication) or another medical condition (e.g. hypothyroidism).

H. The symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment in social, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

Option C: Adjustment disorder is characterized by emotional or behavioral symptoms that develop within 3 months of exposure to an identifiable stressor and usually do not last more than 6 months after the stressor ends.

Option D: Cyclothymic disorder is symptomatically a mild form of bipolar II disorder, characterized by episodes of hypomania and mild depression.

questions.text: On applying firm sliding pressure on unblistered skin in a bullous eruption, the epidermis gets separated from the dermis in some conditions, as shown in the image given below. In which of the following conditions is this sign not seen?
questions.solution:
The sign shown in the image, which is elicited by applying firm tangential sliding pressure with a finger on lesional or perilesional skin is called Nikolsky's sign. This sign is not elicited in epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

In Nikolsky's sign, a tangential/lateral pressure applied on the affected, perilesional or normal skin around the blister, results in separation between the upper and lower layers of the epidermis, producing an erosion. It is positive when there is extension of the blister with or without removal of epidermis in the tested area. This is because the underlying pathology is common to the affected as well as the normal skin.


Nikolsky's sign is found to be positive in the following conditions:

  • Pemphigus vulgaris
  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome(SSSS)
  • Pemphigus foliaceus
  • Bullous eruptions in chikungunya infection
  • Severe cases of acute graft vs host disease

Nikolsky sign is negative in bullous pemphigoid and generalized epidermolysis bullosa simplex.

Nikolsky's sign can be wet or dry depending on the underlying type of skin that is seen after elicited after applying the pressure. Active pemphigus vulgaris will elicit a wet sign while a dry sign is seen with pemphigus foliaceus or in reepithelialisation beneath a pemphigus vulgaris blister.

Marginal Nikolsky’s sign occurs when there is an extension of erosion onto the normal skin, surrounding the lesion. This is elicited by rubbing the skin surrounding the existing lesions.

Direct Nikolsky’s sign is elicited by the induction of erosions on the normal skin that are far from the lesions.

Microscopic Nikolsky’s sign may be a better and sensitive method for rapid diagnosis of epidermal acantholysis. It refers to the classical microscopic changes for pemphigus vulgaris or pemphigus foliaceus in the epidermis, that can be confirmed by a skin biopsy.

Note:

False Nikolsky’s sign/Sheklakov’s sign is positive in sub-epidermal blistering disorders like:

  • Bullous pemphigoid
  • Cicatricial pemphigoid
  • Dermatitis herpetiformis
  • Epidermolysis bullosa
  • Bullous systemic lupus eythematosis

It is seen after pulling the peripheral remnant roof of a ruptured blister, thereby extending the erosions onto the surrounding normal skin, which are limited in size, do not extend spontaneously and heal rapidly.

Pseudo-Nikolsky sign/epidermal peeling sign occurs where epidermal separation is due to the necrosis of epidermal cells, instead of acantholysis, which is seen in the true Nikolsky's sign. A pseudo-Nikolsky sign can be elicited only in affected areas of the skin. This sign is positive in:

  • Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
  • Toxic epidermal necrolysis
  • Bullous ichthyosiform erythroderma
  • Some burn cases

Nikolsky's phenomenon is elicited on palpation by feeling the movement of the detached epidermis over the dermis. This results in the formation of blisters after some time instead of an immediate reaction to form Nikolsky's sign.

questions.text: A young man presents with diarrhea and abdominal pain. There is a rash around his neck as shown in the image below. He follows a maize-based diet. Which of the following is measured for the diagnosis of his condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing Casal’s necklace around the neck is suggestive of pellagra (niacin or vitamin B3 deficiency). 2-methyl nicotinamide is measured for the diagnosis of this condition. 

Niacin is a nutrient that is synthesized in the body from tryptophan. The term niacin represents two compounds nicotinic acid and nicotinamide. It acts as a precursor for the coenzymes NAD and NADP, which are important in various oxidation and reduction reactions.

Niacin deficiency causes pellagra. It is usually seen in individuals with a corn/ maize-based staple diet, a history of alcohol consumption, Hartnup disease, and carcinoid syndrome. 

The primary manifestations of pellagra are often referred to as the 4 Ds: diarrhea, dermatitis, dementia, leading to death. Other manifestations include: 

  • Abdominal pain, loss of appetite
  • Bright red glossitis
  • Generalized weakness, irritability
  • Casal’s necklace - pigmented scaly skin rash around the neck.

It is diagnosed by measuring urinary levels of 2-methyl nicotinamide and 2-pyridone. Treatment is oral supplementation of 100–200 mg of nicotinamide or nicotinic acid three times daily for 5 days.

Other options:

Options B and C: Red blood cell or urinary riboflavin concentrations and RBC glutathione reductase activity measurement are used in the laboratory diagnosis of riboflavin deficiency (vitamin B2 deficiency).

Option D: Functional enzymatic assay of transketolase activity measured before and after the addition of thiamine pyrophosphate is used to diagnose thiamine deficiency (vitamin B1 deficiency).

questions.text: Which of the following visual field defects demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe?
questions.solution:
Image 3 (Superior quadrantanopia) demonstrates a lesion in the optic radiation in the temporal lobe.

Superior quadrantanopia in image 3 (pie in the sky) is seen in patients who have an injury to the optic radiations, which pass through the temporal lobe. They are also known as Meyer’s loop.

Image 1: Bilateral hemianopia occurs due to a defect in the optic tract.

Image 2: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia (pie on the floor) defect is due to the involvement of superior fibers of the optic radiations – Baum’s loop. It is seen in parietal lobe lesions.

Image 4: Right contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to a defect in the visual cortex in the occipital lobe.

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presents to the emergency room with intermittent palpitations, headache, and sweating. There have been multiple such episodes in the past. During these episodes, his blood pressure is found to be elevated. Ultrasonography reveals a suprarenal mass and elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine. What is the next best step in the clinical management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette with elevated 24-hour urinary metanephrine is suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The next step is an MRI to localize the site of the tumor.

MRI is preferred for the localization of pathologies because contrast media used for CT scans can provoke paroxysms. Also, with the MRI, exposure to radiation is reduced in the case of children and pregnant women. Classically, pheochromocytomas show a ‘Swiss cheese’ configuration.

Pheochromocytoma:

Pheochromocytomas may occur in isolation or be associated with hereditary tumor syndromes. The latter include neurofibromatosis type 1, multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2), familial paraganglioma syndrome, and Von Hippel-Lindau syndromes. 

 The tumor syndromes are characterized by unique germline mutations of genes. 

  • Neurofibromatosis type 1 is characterized by NF1 germline mutations.
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome - Germline mutations within succinate dehydrogenase complex subunit B (SDHB), SDHD, SDHC genes.
  • MEN2 - Activating germline mutations of RET proto-oncogene.
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome - Germline mutations in VHL gene.

Note:

An adrenal mass should never be biopsied until the pheochromocytoma has been biochemically excluded. The only indication for an adrenal gland biopsy is to confirm adrenal gland metastasis.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

Related Pearl: Pheochromocytoma

Features:

  • When pheochromocytoma is associated with the MEN syndrome it is rarely malignant.
  • Phaeochromocytomas are greyish-pink on the cut surface and are usually highly vascularised.
  • Zellbalen cells and nuclei with salt and pepper chromatin are seen.

Factors indicating more chances of malignancy:

  • An increased PASS (phaeochromocytoma of the adrenal gland scale score)
  • High number of Ki-67-positive cells
  • Vascular invasion or a breached capsule

Diagnosis:

  • Measurement of the plasma metanephrines is the most sensitive screening test.
  • MRI is the IOC.
  • Biopsy and CT Contrast scans are contraindicated in order to avoid a hypertensive crisis.

Treatment:

  • Adrenalectomy is preferred TOC.
  • Size<5 cm -  Laparoscopic adrenalectomy
  • Preop Alpha blockers should be given
  • Mitotane should be started as adjuvant or palliative treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not a prokinetic?
questions.solution:
Diphenylmethane is not a prokinetic agent. Its derivative (Bisacodyl) is used as a laxative.

Prokinetic agents are the drugs that increase GI motility and transit of material in the GI tract. These agents include:

  • Dopamine receptor antagonists- metoclopramide and domperidone
  • Serotonin receptor agonists- cisapride and prucalopride
  • Motilin
  • Macrolide antibiotics mimicking motilin - erythromycin
  • Miscellaneous agents:
    • Sincalide (C-terminal octapeptide of CCK)
    • Camicinal (motilin receptor agonist)
    • Relamorelin (ghrelin receptor agonist)
    • Velusetrag and naronapride (5HT4 agonists)
